subject: Re: [junit] Re: And now for something completely different: The Way of Testivus
msgSnippet: ... OK. ... Perhaps I m just reacting strongly to the term dogma because I have been accused of being dogmatic in the past when I honestly believe I have not
messageBody:
albsavoia wrote:

> In my mind, I've never associated you with unit testing dogma - quite
> the contrary.

OK.

> I chose my words very, VERY, carefully when talking about unit testing
> dogma, and the word is used only in the subtitle and one epigram. I
> chose the words carefully because I believe that *some* dogma is
> necessary - one has to have a basic position, some ground on which to
> stand - hence the phrase "LESS unit testing dogma" as opposed to "NO
> unit testing dogma."

Perhaps I'm just reacting strongly to the term "dogma" because I have
been accused of being dogmatic in the past when I honestly believe I
have not been. That might be it.

> Testivus itself can be seen as dogmatic in a few places. For example,
> "If you write code write tests", is not exactly wishy-washy about the
> fact that developers should test.

Indeed.

> The epigram "Don't get stuck on unit testing dogma" is aimed as much at
> Testivus as it is to anything else, and the key part of the sentence is
> "Don't get STUCK", don't let blind following of dogma kill your
> creativity or your flexibility.
>
> I hope this clarifies things somewhat.

I suspect the issue is on my side of the fence, and not yours.
